Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Indocyanine Green Fluorescence Imaging in Minimally Invasive Rectal Cancer Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: open-label, phase III randomised controlled trial

Participants.evidence: Patients with stage 0–III rectal carcinoma less than 12 cm from the anal verge, scheduled for minimally invasive sphincter-preserving surgery

Intervention.evidence: randomised 1:1 to receive ICG-FI (ICG+ group) or no ICG-FI (ICG− group)

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the anastomotic leakage rate (grade A+B+C) within 30 days post-surgery

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computerised, and allocation was not concealed

Blinding.evidence: Neither patients nor clinicians were blinded

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between December 2018 and February 2021, 850 patients were randomised (422 to ICG+ and 417 to ICG−)

Number_Analysed.evidence: The modified intention-to-treat analysis included 839 patients

Result_Outcome.evidence: The anastomotic leakage rate was 7.6% in the ICG+ group versus 11.8% in the ICG− group (relative risk 0.645; 95% CI 0.422–0.987; p = 0.041)

Harms.evidence: No adverse events related to ICG were reported
